bibl.title: Letter from Bertha L. Lyons to Philip Showalter Hench, April 14, 1948

div1.p: Lyons thanks Hench for the photograph of Reed's grave and discusses courtesy lines and other details in reference to the copies of Reed items provided by Hench for the Hall of Fame exhibit.

div1.head: Letter from Bertha L. Lyons to Philip Showalter Hench, April 14, 1948
div1.opener:
Every American is a shareholder in the Hall of Fame
HALL OF FAME : NEW YORK UNIVERSITY
I MADISON AVENUE · NEW YORK IO, N. Y.
14 April 1948
Telephone: MURRAY HILL 3-4469
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I am again indebted to you for your very compre-
hensive letter of April 13, and for the copies of the photostatsgraphs
of the Walter Reed grave at Arlington. The large photostat, as
you say, is not too clear, and I have just written to General
Bliss's assistant, Colonel McNinch, asking him to kindly send
me another photostat. If he sends me a good one I shall be glad
to turn it over to you after our ceremony. In the meantime I am
holding the large one which you sent to me and the small ones
awaiting Colonel McNinch's reply.

I am glad that you wrote to General Reed and
Mrs. Blossom Reed asking them about the matter of the courtesy
line to be used throughout the program in connection with Walter
Reed's letters and I shall await their decision in the matter.
I had a long session with my printer a few days ago and another
one today, and have turned over to him most of the material for
the making of cuts. I do not recall now whether I told you that
Dr. Bettmann decided to permit us to use the wood cut and the
drawing which you suggested, gratis, but with this proviso, that
we do not disclose the periodicals in which they appeared. Under
the circumstances, we have consented to treat the material in
this way.

My item No. 8 mentioned in your letter, viz. the
letter from “General” Reed to Major Kean of September 6, 1900,
should have been letter from Walter Reed. That was my error
and I hope you will pardon this temporary lapse of memory.

As suggested, I have just communicated with Miss
Lucy Howard concerning the letter which Walter Reed wrote to
her father, and I am hoping that she will permit not only the use
of the letter but will give me the proper courtesy line.

I am sorry that we left out the Congressional
Medal for I see now that you would have liked to have seen it
reproduced in the program. Frankly, the only reason that we
left it out was because we had reached the point where space was
becoming rather limited, but I assure you that when the cuts are
made of the photographs and manuscripts and we find that we have
an appropriate setting somewhere in the program, we shall bear the
medal in mind and run it.

You are a very generous person to offer all of these
photostats to us as your personal contribution to the Reed fund,
and I personally feel so indebted to you now that I hardly know how
to thank you further. Perhaps when I see you at the ceremony I
can be a little more articulate on this subject. Meantime, let me
assure that you will have a very good seat in the reserved section
as a participant in the Procession, and if for any reason your
plane should be late and you cannot walk in the Procession, your
seat will be reserved. As for the programs, it will be a great
pleasure to send you fifty copies as soon as they are off the
press, without charge.

I regret very much that Mrs. Hench will not
accompany you for I am sure she would have enjoyed the ceremony.
There will be some beautiful music as well as appropriate addresses.

Again with the very deepest appreciation, believe
me
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, Bertha L. Lyons
Assistant to the Director BLL:yz
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
Do pardon the corrections in this letter - but I wanted to
get it off to you this evening. Many of these letters
B L.L.
sound like so much greek to
our stenographer! A temporary one!
